metadata.case_name: Various Petitioners v. Union of India & Ors.
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petitions Nos. 97, 97A, 44, 86 to 88, 111, 112, 85, 158, 211 to 251 and 225 to 229 of 1956

facts.text: Petitioners in Petitions Nos. 97 and 97A are M/s. Pannalal Binjrai, oilmill owners, merchants and commission agents at Sahibganj with branch at Calcutta, and R.B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury, erstwhile karta of HUF. Assessed by ITO Special Circle Patna before transfers.

On September 28, 1954, Central Board of Revenue transferred their cases to ITO Central Circle XI, Calcutta. On January 22, 1955, petitioner No. 2's case to ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi; on July 12, 1955, petitioner No. 1's case to same.
After transfers, ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi instituted proceedings, including assessments and penalty for non-payment.

Petitioner in Petition No. 44/56 is Shri A.L. Sud, sole proprietor of M/s. Amritlal Sud Construction, residing in Calcutta since 1948, originally from Hoshiarpur. Assessed by ITO Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta before June 29, 1955.
On June 29, 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred his case to ITO Special Circle, Ambala, who continued proceedings and assessed for 1946-47 and 1947-48.
Petitioners in Petition No. 85/56 are M/s. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, merchants at Hoshiarpur. Assessed by ITO Hoshiarpur before October 20, 1953 transfer by Commissioner to ITO Special Circle, Ambala.
On October 20, 1953, Commissioner transferred case to ITO Special Circle, Ambala, who reopened assessments 1944-45 to 1950-51 and completed some.
Shri A.L. Sud is member of HUF M/s. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons.

Amritsar group (Petitions 86,87,88,111,112,158/56): Family members directors of Hindustan Embroidery Mills Pvt Ltd at Amritsar. Assessed by ITO A Ward or F Ward Amritsar before transfers around June 29, 1953 by Commissioner to ITO Special Circle Amritsar. Notices under s.34 issued.
Petitioner in 158/56: Shri Ram Saran Das Kapur, HUF at Amritsar, transferred in 1954.

Sriram Jhabarmull group (211-215/56): Nandram Agarwalla, sole proprietor at Kalimpong with Calcutta branch. Assessed by ITO Jalpaiguri before multiple transfers in 1946, including July 27, 1946 by Commissioner Central Calcutta under s.5(7A) to ITO Central Circle IV Calcutta. Assessments completed pre-Constitution.

Raichur group (225-229/56): Kalloor Siddannal at Raichur, Hyderabad. Assessed under Hyderabad Act then Indian Act by Additional ITO Raichur. On December 21, 1953, Commissioner Hyderabad transferred to ITO Special Circle Hyderabad. Later, before May 19, 1955, transferred back to main ITO Raichur.
Assessments made March-April 1955; application under s.27 for 1950-51.

Petitioners in 97,97A cases referred to Income-tax Investigation Commission for evasion over Rs.8 lakhs, widespread activities. Post-Surajmull and Meenakshi Mills decisions, cases reopened under s.34(1A), assigned to special circles for efficiency.
A.L. Sud and Bhagwan Das Sud Sons: evasion over Rs.30 lakhs, interrelated transactions, widespread activities in multiple places.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing Arts. 14 and 19(1)(g).
Whether specific transfer orders are omnibus/wholesale and invalid per Bidi Supply Co., or discriminatory/mala fide.
Effect of explanation added to s.5(7A) by 1956 Amendment.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.5(7A) invests naked arbitrary power to transfer cases without guidelines, discriminatory, picks one assessee over others similarly situated, violates right under s.64(1),(2) to local assessment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arts.14, 19(1)(g); s.64(1),(2),(5); Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India (minority view)

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfers cause inconvenience/harassment, e.g., from Calcutta to Delhi/Ambala.
Omnibus orders invalid per Bidi Supply majority.

respondent_arguments.text: S.5(7A) for administrative convenience to handle special cases like widespread activities, evasion; no differential procedure, same appeals available.
S.64 right not absolute, yields to tax collection exigencies; transfers minimize inconvenience, hearings at assessee's place if requested.
Explanation to s.5(7A) validates omnibus orders; power in high officials, presume bona fides; challenge abuse, not provision.

court_reasoning.text: S.64 confers benefit/right to local assessment, but subject to tax collection exigencies; s.5(7A) enables efficient assessment for complex cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power guided by Act's purpose (assessment/collection), not arbitrary; minor deviation from s.64 not discriminatory.

court_reasoning.text: No material discrimination: same procedure post-transfer; vested in high officials, presume proper exercise; courts can quash abuse.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discretion not on fundamental right; inconvenience not substantial.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation expands 'case' to include all pending/future proceedings; validates transfers for all years.
Pre-Constitution transfers (Sriram) not challengeable under Art.13; acquiescence in others (Amritsar, Raichur); no discrimination in facts (Pannalal, Sud).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfers for administrative convenience in evasion cases.

holdings.text: S.5(7A) intra vires, not violative of Arts.14,19(1)(g); explanation valid.
Specific orders not discriminatory/mala fide; some barred by acquiescence/pre-Constitution effect.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Omnibus orders not contemplated; left constitutionality open; minority held ultra vires.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Discrimination if procedure materially different; minor deviations ok.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dayaldas Kushiram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Central
precedents_cited.relevance: Led to s.5(7A); s.64 for local assessment as far as practicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
Dwarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Power must be hedged with restrictions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surajmull Mohta v. A.V. Viswanatha Sastri
Meenakshi Mills Ltd. v. Viswanatha Sastri
precedents_cited.relevance: Struck down s.5(1) Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer powers, place of assessment; s.5(7A) upheld as administrative for tax collection.

outcome.summary: Court upheld constitutionality of s.5(7A) and explanation; specific transfers valid/not challengeable; petitions dismissed as no discrimination/mala fides proven.

key_quotes.text: "S.5(7A) is a provision for administrative convenience... power is guided and controlled by the purpose which is to be achieved by the Act itself."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The power which is vested in the Commissioner of Income-tax and the Central Board of Revenue is a naked and arbitrary power unguided and uncontrolled by any rules."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel

key_quotes.text: "It would be prudent if the principles of natural justice are followed... notice is given to the party affected."
key_quotes.speaker: court
